pull.title: qa: Only allow disconnecting all NodeConns
pull.body:
Disconnecting the connection with `index=0` makes no sense when there are more than one connections, as the list "rotates around" and populates index 0 after `del`.

Just disconnect all NodeConns in any case.

events.message: qa: Only allow disconnecting all NodeConns

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,7 +54,7 @@ def run_test(self):
         # p2p_conns[2] will test resetting the counters
         p2p_conns = []
 
-        for i in range(3):
+        for _ in range(3):
comments.body:
Interested in the use of the underscore as the variable name here, did some reading and from what I've read use of the underscore only works as something other than a variable name when used in an interactive python shell? Other than that people seem to believe it's a bad naming convention.

Context: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26895362/what-does-in-python-do

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,7 +54,7 @@ def run_test(self):
         # p2p_conns[2] will test resetting the counters
         p2p_conns = []
 
-        for i in range(3):
+        for _ in range(3):
comments.body: `_` as a variable name in python is a convention to indicate that the result won't be used.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,7 +54,7 @@ def run_test(self):
         # p2p_conns[2] will test resetting the counters
         p2p_conns = []
 
-        for i in range(3):
+        for _ in range(3):
comments.body: Thanks for the explanation, makes sense.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -182,13 +182,15 @@ def p2p(self):
         assert self.p2ps, "No p2p connection"
         return self.p2ps[0]
 
-    def disconnect_p2p(self, index=0):
-        """Close the p2p connection to the node."""
-        # Connection could have already been closed by other end. Calling disconnect_p2p()
-        # on an already disconnected p2p connection is not an error.
-        if self.p2ps[index].connection is not None:
-            self.p2ps[index].connection.disconnect_node()
-        del self.p2ps[index]
+    def disconnect_p2ps(self):
+        """Close all p2p connections to the node."""
+        for _ in range(len(self.p2ps)):
+            index = 0
+            # Connection could have already been closed by other end.
comments.body:
Is the order of deletion relevant? If not, something like this is both easier to read and likely more efficient:
```
for x in self.p2ps:
    if x.connection is not None:
        x.connection.disconnect_node()
self.p2ps = []
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -182,13 +182,15 @@ def p2p(self):
         assert self.p2ps, "No p2p connection"
         return self.p2ps[0]
 
-    def disconnect_p2p(self, index=0):
-        """Close the p2p connection to the node."""
-        # Connection could have already been closed by other end. Calling disconnect_p2p()
-        # on an already disconnected p2p connection is not an error.
-        if self.p2ps[index].connection is not None:
-            self.p2ps[index].connection.disconnect_node()
-        del self.p2ps[index]
+    def disconnect_p2ps(self):
+        """Close all p2p connections to the node."""
+        for _ in range(len(self.p2ps)):
+            index = 0
+            # Connection could have already been closed by other end.
comments.body: No, the order is not relevant. Will switch to your suggestion. (I tried to minimize the --ignore-all-space diff)
